documentation.title: tdigest_merge()
documentation.description:
Merges tdigest results across the group.

For more information about the underlying algorithm (T-Digest) and the estimated error, see estimation error in percentiles.

> The `tdigest_merge()` and `merge_tdigest()` functions are equivalent

> 
>The results of tdigest() and tdigest_merge() can be stored and later retrieved. For example, you may want to create daily percentiles summary, which can then be used to calculate weekly percentiles.
> However, the precise binary representation of these results may change over time. There's no guarantee that these functions will produce identical results for identical inputs, and therefore we don't advise relying on them.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns the merged tdigest values of *expr* across the group.

> 
>
> * Use the function percentile_tdigest() to calculate the percentiles from the `tdigest_merge` results.
> * All tdigests that are included in the same group must be of the same type.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for the aggregation calculation.|
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| summarize PreAggDamageProperty=tdigest(DamageProperty) by State
| summarize tdigest_merge(PreAggDamageProperty)

documentation.title: tobool()
documentation.description:
Convert inputs to boolean (signed 8-bit) representation.

> The `tobool()` and `toboolean()` functions are equivalent

> 
> When possible, use bool literals instead.
documentation.returnInfo:
If conversion is successful, result will be a boolean.
If conversion isn't successful, result will be `null`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | `string` |  *True* | The value to convert to boolean.|
documentation.example:
tobool("true") == true
tobool("false") == false
tobool(1) == true
tobool(123) == true

documentation.title: todatetime()
documentation.description:
Converts the input to a datetime scalar value.

> 
>
> * To learn more about supported data and time formats and syntax, see The datetime data type.
> * When possible, use datetime literals instead of the `todatetime()` function.
documentation.returnInfo:
If the conversion is successful, the result is a datetime value.
Else, the result is `null`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | scalar |  *True* | The value to convert to datetime.|
documentation.example:
print todatetime("2015-12-31 23:59:59.9")

print todatetime('12-02-2022') == datetime('12-02-2022')

documentation.title: todecimal()
documentation.description:
Converts the input to a decimal number representation.

> 
> When possible, use decimal literals instead.
documentation.returnInfo:
If conversion is successful, result is a decimal number.
If conversion isn't successful, result is `null`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | scalar |  *True* | The value to convert to a decimal.|
documentation.example: print todecimal("123.45678") == decimal(123.45678)

documentation.title: toguid()
documentation.description:
Converts a string to a `guid` scalar.

> 
> When possible, use guid literals instead.
documentation.returnInfo:
The conversion process takes the first 32 characters of the input, ignoring properly located hyphens, validates that the characters are between 0-9 or a-f, and then converts the string into a `guid` scalar. The rest of the string is ignored.

If the conversion is successful, the result is a `guid` scalar. Otherwise, the result is `null`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | scalar |  *True* | The value to convert to guid.|
documentation.example:
datatable(str: string)
[
    "0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef",
    "0123456789ab-cdef-0123-456789abcdef",
    "a string that is not a guid"
]
| extend guid = toguid(str)

documentation.title: tohex()
documentation.description: Converts input to a hexadecimal string.
documentation.returnInfo:
If conversion is successful, result is a string value.
If conversion isn't successful, result is `null`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | int or long |  *True* | The value that is converted to a hex string.|
| *minLength* | `int` | | The value representing the number of leading characters to include in the output. Values between 1 and 16 are supported. Values greater than 16 are truncated to 16. If the string is longer than *minLength* without leading characters, then *minLength* is effectively ignored. Negative numbers are only represented at minimum by their underlying data size, so for an integer (32-bit) the *minLength* is at minimum 8, for a long (64-bit) it's at minimum 16.|
documentation.example:
print
    tohex(256) == '100',
    tohex(-256) == 'ffffffffffffff00', // 64-bit 2's complement of -256
    tohex(toint(-256), 8) == 'ffffff00', // 32-bit 2's complement of -256
    tohex(256, 8) == '00000100',
    tohex(256, 2) == '100' // Exceeds min length of 2, so min length is ignored.

documentation.title: toint()
documentation.description:
Converts the input to an integer value (signed 32-bit) number representation.

> 
> When possible, use int literals instead.
documentation.returnInfo: If the conversion is successful, the result is an integer. Otherwise, the result is `null`. If the input includes a decimal value, the result truncate to only the integer portion.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | scalar |  *True* | The value to convert to an integer.|

documentation.title: tolong()
documentation.description:
Converts the input value to a long (signed 64-bit) number representation.

> 
> When possible, use long literals instead.
documentation.returnInfo:
If conversion is successful, the result is a long number.
If conversion isn't successful, the result is `null`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | scalar |  *True* | The value to convert to a long.|

documentation.title: tolower()
documentation.description: Converts the input string to lower case.
documentation.returnInfo:
If conversion is successful, result is a lowercase string.
If conversion isn't successful, result is `null`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | `string` |  *True* | The value to convert to a lowercase string.|
documentation.example: tolower("Hello") == "hello"

documentation.title: toreal()
documentation.description:
Converts the input expression to a value of type real.

> The `todouble()` and `toreal()` functions are equivalent.

> 
> When possible, use real literals instead.
documentation.returnInfo: If conversion is successful, the result is a value of type `real`. Otherwise, the returned value is `real(null)`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | scalar |  *True* | The value to convert to real.|

documentation.title: tostring()
documentation.description: Converts the input to a string representation.
documentation.returnInfo:
If *value* is non-null, the result is a string representation of *value*.
If *value* is null, the result is an empty string.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | scalar |  *True* | The value to convert to a string.|
documentation.example: print tostring(123)

documentation.title: totimespan()
documentation.description:
Converts the input to a timespan scalar value.

> **Deprecated aliases:** totime()

> 
> When possible, we recommend using timespan literals instead.
documentation.returnInfo:
If conversion is successful, result is a timespan value.
Else, result is null.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | `string` |  *True* | The value to convert to a timespan.|

documentation.title: toupper()
documentation.description: Converts a string to upper case.
documentation.returnInfo:
If conversion is successful, result is an uppercase string.
If conversion isn't successful, result is `null`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | `string` |  *True* | The value to convert to an uppercase string.|
documentation.example: toupper("hello") == "HELLO"

documentation.title: translate()
documentation.description:
Replaces a set of characters ('searchList') with another set of characters ('replacementList') in a given a string.
The function searches for characters in the 'searchList' and replaces them with the corresponding characters in 'replacementList'
documentation.returnInfo: *source* after replacing all occurrences of characters in 'replacementList' with the corresponding characters in 'searchList'
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *searchList* | `string` |  *True* | The list of characters that should be replaced.|
| *replacementList* | `string` |  *True* | The list of characters that should replace the characters in *searchList*.|
| *source* | `string` |  *True* | A string to search.|

documentation.title: treepath()
documentation.description: Enumerates all the path expressions that identify leaves in a dynamic object.
documentation.returnInfo: An array of path expressions.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *object* | `dynamic` |  *True*| A dynamic property bag object for which to enumerate the path expressions.|

documentation.title: trim()
documentation.description: Removes all leading and trailing matches of the specified regular expression.
documentation.returnInfo: *source* after trimming matches of *regex* found in the beginning and/or the end of *source*.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *regex* | `string` |  *True* | The string or regular expression to be trimmed from *source*.|
| *source* | `string` |  *True* | The source string from which to trim *regex*.|

documentation.title: trim_end()
documentation.description: Removes trailing match of the specified regular expression.
documentation.returnInfo: *source* after trimming matches of *regex* found in the end of *source*.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *regex* | `string` |  *True* | The string or regular expression to be trimmed from the end of *source*.|
| *source* | `string` |  *True* | The source string from which to trim *regex*.|

documentation.title: trim_start()
documentation.description: Removes leading match of the specified regular expression.
documentation.returnInfo: *source* after trimming match of *regex* found in the beginning of *source*.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *regex* | `string` |  *True* | The string or regular expression to be trimmed from the beginning of *source*.|
| *source* | `string` |  *True* | The source string from which to trim *regex*.|

documentation.title: unicode_codepoints_from_string()
documentation.description:
Returns a dynamic array of the Unicode codepoints of the input string. This function is the inverse operation of `unicode_codepoints_to_string()` function.

> **Deprecated aliases:** to_utf8()
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a dynamic array of the Unicode codepoints of the characters that make up the string provided to this function.
See `unicode_codepoints_to_string()`)
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | `string` |  *True* | The source string to convert. |
documentation.example:
print arr = unicode_codepoints_from_string("")

print arr = unicode_codepoints_from_string(" - Kusto")

print str = unicode_codepoints_to_string(unicode_codepoints_from_string("Kusto"))

documentation.title: unicode_codepoints_to_string()
documentation.description:
Returns the string represented by the Unicode codepoints. This function is the inverse operation of `unicode_codepoints_from_string()` function.

> **Deprecated aliases:** make_string()
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns the string made of the UTF characters whose Unicode codepoint value is provided by the arguments to this function. The input must consist of valid Unicode codepoints.
If any argument isn't a valid Unicode codepoint, the function returns `null`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *values* | int, long, or dynamic |  *True* | One or more comma-separated values to convert. The values may also be a dynamic array.|

> 
> This function receives up to 64 arguments.
documentation.example:
print str = unicode_codepoints_to_string(75, 117, 115, 116, 111)

print str = unicode_codepoints_to_string(dynamic([75, 117, 115, 116, 111]))

print str = unicode_codepoints_to_string(dynamic([75, 117, 115]), 116, 111)

print str = unicode_codepoints_to_string(75, 10, 117, 10, 115, 10, 116, 10, 111)

print str = unicode_codepoints_to_string(range(48,57), range(65,90), range(97,122))

documentation.title: unixtime_microseconds_todatetime()
documentation.description: Converts unix-epoch microseconds to UTC datetime.
documentation.returnInfo: If the conversion is successful, the result is a datetime value. Otherwise, the result is null.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *microseconds* | `real` |  *True* | The epoch timestamp in microseconds. A `datetime` value that occurs before the epoch time (1970-01-01 00:00:00) has a negative timestamp value.|
documentation.example: print date_time = unixtime_microseconds_todatetime(1546300800000000)

documentation.title: unixtime_milliseconds_todatetime()
documentation.description: Converts unix-epoch milliseconds to UTC datetime.
documentation.returnInfo: If the conversion is successful, the result is a datetime value. Otherwise, the result is null.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *milliseconds* | `real` |  *True* | The epoch timestamp in microseconds. A `datetime` value that occurs before the epoch time (1970-01-01 00:00:00) has a negative timestamp value.|
documentation.example: print date_time = unixtime_milliseconds_todatetime(1546300800000)

documentation.title: unixtime_nanoseconds_todatetime()
documentation.description: Converts unix-epoch nanoseconds to UTC datetime.
documentation.returnInfo: If the conversion is successful, the result is a datetime value. Otherwise, the result is null.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *nanoseconds* | `real` |  *True* | The epoch timestamp in nanoseconds. A `datetime` value that occurs before the epoch time (1970-01-01 00:00:00) has a negative timestamp value.|
documentation.example: print date_time = unixtime_nanoseconds_todatetime(1546300800000000000)

documentation.title: unixtime_seconds_todatetime()
documentation.description: Converts unix-epoch seconds to UTC datetime.
documentation.returnInfo: If the conversion is successful, the result is a datetime value. Otherwise, the result is null.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *seconds* | `real` |  *True* | The epoch timestamp in seconds. A `datetime` value that occurs before the epoch time (1970-01-01 00:00:00) has a negative timestamp value.|
documentation.example: print date_time = unixtime_seconds_todatetime(1546300800)

documentation.title: url_decode()
documentation.description:
The function converts an encoded URL into a regular URL representation.

For more information about URL encoding and decoding, see Percent-encoding.
documentation.returnInfo: URL (string) in a regular representation.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *encoded_url* | `string` |  *True* | The encoded URL to decode.|
documentation.example:
let url = @'https%3a%2f%2fwww.bing.com%2f';
print original = url, decoded = url_decode(url)

documentation.title: url_encode()
documentation.description:
The function converts characters of the input URL into a format that can be transmitted over the internet.
Differs from url_encode_component by encoding spaces as '+' and not as '%20' (see application/x-www-form-urlencoded here).

For more information about URL encoding and decoding, see Percent-encoding.
documentation.returnInfo: URL (string) converted into a format that can be transmitted over the Internet.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*url*| `string` | *True*|The URL to encode.|
documentation.example:
let url = @'https://www.bing.com/hello world';
print original = url, encoded = url_encode(url)

documentation.title: url_encode_component()
documentation.description:
The function converts characters of the input URL into a format that can be transmitted over the internet. Differs from url_encode by encoding spaces as '%20' and not as '+'.

For more information about URL encoding and decoding, see Percent-encoding.
documentation.returnInfo: URL (string) converted into a format that can be transmitted over the Internet.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *url* | `string` |  *True* | The URL to encode.|
documentation.example:
let url = @'https://www.bing.com/hello world/';
print original = url, encoded = url_encode_component(url)

documentation.title: week_of_year()
documentation.description:
Returns an integer that represents the week number. The week number is calculated from the first week of a year, which is the one that includes the first Thursday, according to ISO 8601.

 **Deprecated aliases:** weekofyear()

> 
> `weekofyear()` wasn't ISO 8601 compliant; the first week of a year was defined as the week with the year's first Wednesday in it.
documentation.returnInfo: `week number` - The week number that contains the given date.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *date* | `datetime` |  *True* | The date for which to return the week of the year.|

documentation.title: welch_test()
documentation.description: Computes the p_value of the Welch-test function
documentation.returnInfo:
From Wikipedia:

In statistics, Welch's t-test is a two-sample location test that's used to test the hypothesis that two populations have equal means.
Welch's t-test is an adaptation of Student's t-test, and is more reliable when the two samples have unequal variances and unequal sample sizes. These tests are often referred to as "unpaired" or "independent samples" t-tests.
The tests are typically applied when the statistical units underlying the two samples being compared are non-overlapping.
Welch's t-test is less popular than Student's t-test, and may be less familiar to readers. The test is also called "Welch's unequal variances t-test", or "unequal variances t-test".
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *mean1* | real or long |  *True* | The mean (average) value of the first series.|
| *variance1* | real or long |  *True* | The variance value of the first series.|
| *count1* | real or long |  *True* | The count of values in the first series.|
| *mean2* | real or long |  *True* | The mean (average) value of the second series.|
| *variance2* | real or long |  *True* | The variance value of the second series.|
| *count2* | real or long |  *True* | The count of values in the second series.|
documentation.example:
// s1, s2 values are from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welch%27s_t-test
print
    s1 = dynamic([27.5, 21.0, 19.0, 23.6, 17.0, 17.9, 16.9, 20.1, 21.9, 22.6, 23.1, 19.6, 19.0, 21.7, 21.4]),
    s2 = dynamic([27.1, 22.0, 20.8, 23.4, 23.4, 23.5, 25.8, 22.0, 24.8, 20.2, 21.9, 22.1, 22.9, 20.5, 24.4])
| mv-expand s1 to typeof(double), s2 to typeof(double)
| summarize m1=avg(s1), v1=variance(s1), c1=count(), m2=avg(s2), v2=variance(s2), c2=count()
| extend pValue=welch_test(m1,v1,c1,m2,v2,c2)
// pValue = 0.021

documentation.title: zip()
documentation.description:
The `zip` function accepts any number of `dynamic` arrays, and returns an
array whose elements are each an array holding the elements of the input
arrays of the same index.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *arrays* | `dynamic` |  *True* | The dynamic array values to zip. The function accepts between 2-16 arrays.|
documentation.example:
print zip(dynamic([1,3,5]), dynamic([2,4,6]))

print zip(dynamic(["A", 1, 1.5]), dynamic([{}, "B"]))

datatable(a:int, b:string) [1,"one",2,"two",3,"three"]
| summarize a = make_list(a), b = make_list(b)
| project zip(a, b)

documentation.title: arg_max()
documentation.description:
Finds a row in the table that maximizes the specified expression. It returns all columns of the input table or specified columns.

> **Deprecated aliases:** argmax()
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a row in the table that maximizes the specified expression *ExprToMaximize*, and the values of columns specified in *ExprToReturn*.

> 
> To see the maximal value only, use the max() function.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *ExprToMaximize* | `string` |  *True* | The expression for which the maximum value is determined. |
| *ExprToReturn* | `string` |  *True* | The expression determines which columns' values are returned, from the row that has the maximum value for *ExprToMaximize*.  Use a wildcard `*` to return all columns. |

documentation.title: arg_min()
documentation.description:
Finds a row in the table that minimizes the specified expression. It returns all columns of the input table or specified columns.

> **Deprecated aliases:** argmin()
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a row in the table that minimizes *ExprToMinimize*, and the values of columns specified in *ExprToReturn*. Use or `*` to return the entire row.

> 
> To see the minimal value only, use the min() function.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *ExprToMinimize*| `string` |  *True* | The expression for which the minimum value is determined. |
| *ExprToReturn* | `string` |  *True* | The expression determines which columns' values are returned, from the row that has the minimum value for *ExprToMinimize*.  Use a wildcard `*` to return all columns. |

When *ExprToMinimize* is null for all rows in a table, one row in the table is picked. Otherwise, rows where *ExprToMinimize* is null are ignored.
documentation.example:
StormEvents 
| summarize arg_min(BeginLat, BeginLocation) by State

StormEvents
| where DeathsDirect > 0
| summarize arg_min(StartTime, *) by State

datatable(Fruit: string, Color: string, Version: int) [
    "Apple", "Red", 1,
    "Apple", "Green", int(null),
    "Banana", "Yellow", int(null),
    "Banana", "Green", int(null),
    "Pear", "Brown", 1,
    "Pear", "Green", 2,
]
| summarize arg_min(Version, *) by Fruit

documentation.title: avg()
documentation.description: Calculates the average (arithmetic mean) of *expr* across the group.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the average value of *expr* across the group.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for aggregation calculation. Records with `null` values are ignored and not included in the calculation. |
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| summarize AvgDamageToCrops = avg(DamageCrops) by State

documentation.title: avgif()
documentation.description: Calculates the average of *expr* in records for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the average value of *expr* in records where *predicate* evaluates to `true`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for aggregation calculation. Records with `null` values are ignored and not included in the calculation. |
| *predicate* | `string` |  *True* | The predicate that if true, the *expr* calculated value is added to the average. |
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| summarize Averagedamage=tolong(avg( DamageCrops)),AverageWhenDamage=tolong(avgif(DamageCrops,DamageCrops >0)) by State

documentation.title: binary_all_and()
documentation.description: Accumulates values using the binary `AND` operation for each summarization group, or in total if a group isn't specified.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns an aggregated value using the binary `AND` operation over records for each summarization group, or in total if a group isn't specified.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `long` |  *True* | The value used for the binary `AND`  calculation. |
documentation.example:
datatable(num:long)
[
  0xFFFFFFFF, 
  0xFFFFF00F,
  0xCFFFFFFD,
  0xFAFEFFFF,
]
| summarize result = toupper(tohex(binary_all_and(num)))

documentation.title: binary_all_or()
documentation.description: Accumulates values using the binary `OR` operation for each summarization group, or in total if a group isn't specified.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns an aggregated value using the binary `OR` operation over records for each summarization group, or in total if a group isn't specified.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `long` |  *True* | The value used for the binary `OR`  calculation. |
documentation.example:
datatable(num:long)
[
  0x88888008,
  0x42000000,
  0x00767000,
  0x00000005, 
]
| summarize result = toupper(tohex(binary_all_or(num)))

documentation.title: binary_all_xor()
documentation.description: Accumulates values using the binary `XOR` operation for each summarization group, or in total if a group is not specified.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a value that is aggregated using the binary `XOR` operation over records for each summarization group, or in total if a group isn't specified.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `long` |  *True* | The value used for the binary `XOR`  calculation. |
documentation.example:
datatable(num:long)
[
  0x44404440,
  0x1E1E1E1E,
  0x90ABBA09,
  0x000B105A,
]
| summarize result = toupper(tohex(binary_all_xor(num)))

documentation.title: count()
documentation.description: Counts the number of records per summarization group, or total if summarization is done without grouping.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a count of the records per summarization group, or in total if summarization is done without grouping.
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| summarize Count=count() by State

documentation.title: count_distinct()
documentation.description:
Counts unique values specified by the scalar expression per summary group, or the total number of unique values if the summary group is omitted.

If you only need an estimation of unique values count, we recommend using the less resource-consuming `dcount` aggregation function.

To count only records for which a predicate returns `true`, use the count_distinctif aggregation function.

> 
>
> * This function is limited to 100M unique values. An attempt to apply the function on an expression returning too many values produce a runtime error (HRESULT: 0x80DA0012).
:::moniker range="azure-data-explorer"
> * Function performance can be degraded when operating on multiple data sources from different clusters.
::: moniker-end
:::moniker range="microsoft-fabric"
> * Function performance can be degraded when operating on multiple data sources from different Eventhouses.
::: moniker-end
documentation.returnInfo: Long integer value indicating the number of unique values of *expr* per summary group.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr*| scalar |  *True* | The expression whose unique values are to be counted. |
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| summarize UniqueEvents=count_distinct(EventType) by State
| top 5 by UniqueEvents

documentation.title: count_distinctif()
documentation.description:
Conditionally counts unique values specified by the scalar expression per summary group, or the total number of unique values if the summary group is omitted. Only records for which *predicate* evaluates to `true` are counted.

If you only need an estimation of unique values count, we recommend using the less resource-consuming dcountif aggregation function.

> 
>
> * This function is limited to 100M unique values. An attempt to apply the function on an expression returning too many values produces a runtime error (HRESULT: 0x80DA0012).
:::moniker range="azure-data-explorer"
> * Function performance can be degraded when operating on multiple data sources from different clusters.
::: moniker-end
:::moniker range="microsoft-fabric"
> * Function performance can be degraded when operating on multiple data sources from different Eventhouses.
::: moniker-end
documentation.returnInfo: Integer value indicating the number of unique values of *expr* per summary group, for all records for which the *predicate* evaluates to `true`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr*| scalar |  *True* | The expression whose unique values are to be counted. |
| *predicate* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used to filter records to be aggregated. |
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| summarize UniqueFatalEvents=count_distinctif(EventType,(DeathsDirect + DeathsIndirect)>0) by State
| where UniqueFatalEvents > 0
| top 5 by UniqueFatalEvents

documentation.title: countif()
documentation.description: Counts the rows in which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a count of rows in which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *predicate*| `string` |  *True* | The expression used for aggregation calculation. The value can be any scalar expression with a return type of bool.

documentation.title: covariance()
documentation.description:
Calculates the sample covariance of two random variables *expr1* and *expr2*.

The following formula is used:
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the covariance value of *expr1* and *expr2*.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*expr1* | `real` |  *True* | First random variable expression.|
|*expr2* | `real` |  *True* | Second random variable expression.|
documentation.example:
datatable(x:real, y:real) [
    1.0, 14.0,
    2.0, 10.0,
    3.0, 17.0,
    4.0, 20.0,
    5.0, 50.0,
]
| summarize covariance(x, y)

documentation.title: covarianceif()
documentation.description:
Calculates the sample covariance of two random variables *expr1* and *expr2* in records for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.

The following formula is used:
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the covariance value of *expr1* and *expr2* in records for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*expr1* | `real` |  *True* | First random variable expression.|
|*expr2* | `real` |  *True* | Second random variable expression.|
|*predicate*| `string` |  *True* | If *predicate* evaluates to `true`, values of *expr1* and *expr2* will be added to the covariance.|
documentation.example:
range x from 1 to 100 step 1
| extend y = iff(x % 2 == 0, x * 2, x * 3)
| summarize covarianceif(x, y, x % 3 == 0)

documentation.title: covariancep()
documentation.description:
Calculates the population covariance of two random variables *expr1* and *expr2*.

The following formula is used:
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the covariance value of *expr1* and *expr2*.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*expr1* | `real` |  *True* | First random variable expression.|
|*expr2* | `real` |  *True* | Second random variable expression.|
documentation.example:
datatable(x:real, y:real) [
    1.0, 14.0,
    2.0, 10.0,
    3.0, 17.0,
    4.0, 20.0,
    5.0, 50.0,
]
| summarize covariancep(x, y)

documentation.title: covariancepif()
documentation.description:
Calculates the sample covariance of two random variables *expr1* and *expr2* in records for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.

The following formula is used:
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the covariance value of *expr1* and *expr2* in records for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*expr1* | `real` |  *True* | First random variable expression.|
|*expr2* | `real` |  *True* | Second random variable expression.|
|*predicate*| `string` |  *True* | If *predicate* evaluates to `true`, values of *expr1* and *expr2* will be added to the covariance.|
documentation.example:
range x from 1 to 100 step 1
| extend y = iff(x % 2 == 0, x * 2, x * 3)
| summarize covariancepif(x, y, x % 3 == 0)

documentation.title: dcount()
documentation.description:
Calculates an estimate of the number of distinct values that are taken by a scalar expression in the summary group.

> 
> The `dcount()` aggregation function is primarily useful for estimating the cardinality of huge sets. It trades accuracy for performance, and might return a result that varies between executions. The order of inputs might have an effect on its output.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns an estimate of the number of distinct values of *expr* in the group.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr*| `string` |  *True* | The input whose distinct values are to be counted. |
| *accuracy* | `int` |   | The value that defines the requested estimation accuracy. The default value is `1`. See Estimation accuracy for supported values. |
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| summarize DifferentEvents=dcount(EventType) by State
| order by DifferentEvents

documentation.title: dcountif()
documentation.description: Estimates the number of distinct values of *expr* for rows in which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns an estimate of the number of distinct values of *expr* for rows in which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.

> 
> `dcountif()` might return an error in cases where all, or none of the rows pass the `Predicate` expression.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for the aggregation calculation. |
| *predicate* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used to filter rows. |
| *accuracy* | `int` |  | The control between speed and accuracy. If unspecified, the default value is `1`. See Estimation accuracy for supported values. |
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| summarize DifferentFatalEvents=dcountif(EventType,(DeathsDirect + DeathsIndirect)>0) by State
| where DifferentFatalEvents > 0
| order by DifferentFatalEvents

documentation.title: hll()
documentation.description:
The `hll()` function is a way to estimate the number of unique values in a set of values. It does so by calculating intermediate results for aggregation within the summarize operator for a group of data using the `dcount` function.

Read about the underlying algorithm (*H*yper*L*og*L*og) and the estimation accuracy.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns the intermediate results of distinct count of *expr* across the group.

> 
> - The results of hll(), hll_if(), and hll_merge() can be stored and later retrieved. For example, you might want to create a daily unique user summary, which can then be used to calculate weekly counts.
> However, the precise binary representation of these results might change over time. There's no guarantee that these functions produce identical results for identical inputs, and therefore we don't advise relying on them.
> - Use the hll_merge function to merge the results of multiple `hll()` functions.
> - Use the dcount_hll function to calculate the number of distinct values from the output of the `hll()` or `hll_merge` functions.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for the aggregation calculation. |
| *accuracy* | `int` |   | The value that controls the balance between speed and accuracy. If unspecified, the default value is `1`. For supported values, see Estimation accuracy. |
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| summarize hll(DamageProperty) by bin(StartTime,10m)

documentation.title: make_bag()
documentation.description: Creates a `dynamic` JSON property bag (dictionary) of all the values of *expr* in the group.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a `dynamic` JSON property bag (dictionary) of all the values of *Expr* in the group, which are property bags. Nondictionary values are skipped.
If a key appears in more than one row, an arbitrary value, out of the possible values for this key, is selected.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `dynamic` |  *True* | The expression used for the aggregation calculation. |
| *maxSize* | `int` |  | The limit on the maximum number of elements returned. The default and max value is 1048576. |

> 
> `make_dictionary()` has been deprecated in favor of `make_bag()`. The legacy version has a default *maxSize* limit of 128.

documentation.title: make_bag_if()
documentation.description: Creates a `dynamic` JSON property bag (dictionary) of *expr* values in records for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a `dynamic` JSON property bag (dictionary) of *expr* values in records for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`. Nondictionary values are skipped.
If a key appears in more than one row, an arbitrary value, out of the possible values for this key, are selected.

> 
> This function without the predicate is similar to `make_bag`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `dynamic` |  *True* | The expression used for the aggregation calculation. |
| *predicate* | `bool` |  *True* | The predicate that evaluates to `true`, in order for *expr* to be added to the result. |
| *maxSize* | `int` |  | The limit on the maximum number of elements returned. The default and max value is 1048576. |

documentation.title: make_list()
documentation.description:
Creates a `dynamic` array of all the values of *expr* in the group.

> **Deprecated aliases:** makelist()
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a `dynamic` array of all the values of *expr* in the group.
If the input to the `summarize` operator isn't sorted, the order of elements in the resulting array is undefined.
If the input to the `summarize` operator is sorted, the order of elements in the resulting array tracks that of the input.

> 
> Use the `array_sort_asc()` or `array_sort_desc()` function to create an ordered list by some key.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `dynamic` |  *True* | The expression used for the aggregation calculation. |
| *maxSize* | `int` |  | The maximum number of elements returned. The default and max value is 1048576. |

> 
> The deprecated version has a default *maxSize* limit of 128.

documentation.title: make_list_if()
documentation.description: Creates a `dynamic` array of *expr* values in the group for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a `dynamic` array of *expr* values in the group for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.
If the input to the `summarize` operator isn't sorted, the order of elements in the resulting array is undefined.
If the input to the `summarize` operator is sorted, the order of elements in the resulting array tracks that of the input.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for the aggregation calculation. |
| *predicate* | `string` |  *True* | A predicate that has to evaluate to `true` in order for *expr* to be added to the result. |
| *maxSize* | integer |  | The maximum number of elements returned. The default and max value is 1048576. |

documentation.title: make_set()
documentation.description:
Creates a `dynamic` array of the set of distinct values that *expr* takes in the group.

> **Deprecated aliases:** makeset()
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a `dynamic` array of the set of distinct values that *expr* takes in the group.
The array's sort order is undefined.

> 
> To only count distinct values, use dcount() or count_distinct().
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for the aggregation calculation. |
| *maxSize* | `int` |  | The maximum number of elements returned. The default and max value is 1048576. |

> 
> The deprecated version has a default *maxSize* limit of 128.

documentation.title: make_set_if()
documentation.description: Creates a `dynamic` array of the set of distinct values that *expr* takes in records for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a `dynamic` array of the set of distinct values that *expr* takes in records for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`. The array's sort order is undefined.

> 
> To only count the distinct values, use dcountif().
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for the aggregation calculation. |
| *predicate* | `string` |  *True* | A predicate that has to evaluate to `true` in order for *expr* to be added to the result. |
| *maxSize* | `int` |  | The maximum number of elements returned. The default and max value is 1048576. |

documentation.title: max()
documentation.description: Finds the maximum value of the expression in the table.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns the value in the table that maximizes the specified expression.

> 
> This function gives you the max on its own. If you want to see other columns in addition to the max, use arg_max.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression for which the maximum value is determined. |
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| summarize LatestEvent=max(StartTime)

documentation.title: maxif()
documentation.description:
Calculates the maximum value of *expr* in records for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.

See also - max() function, which returns the maximum value across the group without predicate expression.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the maximum value of *expr* in records for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for the aggregation calculation. |
| *predicate* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used to filter rows. |
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| extend Damage=DamageCrops + DamageProperty, Deaths=DeathsDirect + DeathsIndirect
| summarize MaxDamageNoCasualties=maxif(Damage, Deaths == 0) by State

documentation.title: merge_tdigest()
documentation.description:
Merges `tdigest` results (scalar version of the aggregate version `tdigest_merge()`).

Read more about the underlying algorithm (T-Digest) and the estimated error here.

> The `merge_tdigest()` and `tdigest_merge()` functions are equivalent

> 
>The results of tdigest() and tdigest_merge() can be stored and later retrieved. For example, you may want to create daily percentiles summary, which can then be used to calculate weekly percentiles.
> However, the precise binary representation of these results may change over time. There's no guarantee that these functions will produce identical results for identical inputs, and therefore we don't advise relying on them.
documentation.returnInfo: The result for merging the columns `*Expr1*`, `*Expr2*`, ... `*ExprN*` to one `tdigest`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *exprs* | `dynamic` |  *True* | One or more comma-separated column references that have the `tdigest` values to be merged. |
documentation.example:
range x from 1 to 10 step 1 
| extend y = x + 10
| summarize tdigestX = tdigest(x), tdigestY = tdigest(y)
| project merged = merge_tdigest(tdigestX, tdigestY)
| project percentile_tdigest(merged, 100, typeof(long))

documentation.title: min()
documentation.description: Finds the minimum value of the expression in the table.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns the minimum value of *expr* across the table.

> 
> This gives you the min on its own. If you want to see other columns in addition to the min, use arg_min.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression for which the minimum value is determined. |
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| summarize FirstEvent=min(StartTime)

documentation.title: minif()
documentation.description:
Returns the minimum of *Expr* in records for which *Predicate* evaluates to `true`.

* Can be used only in context of aggregation inside summarize

See also - min() function, which returns the minimum value across the group without predicate expression.
documentation.returnInfo: The minimum value of *Expr* in records for which *Predicate* evaluates to `true`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *Expr* | `string` |  *True* | Expression that will be used for aggregation calculation. |
| *Predicate* | `string` |  *True* | Expression that will be used to filter rows. |
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| extend Damage=DamageCrops+DamageProperty, Deaths=DeathsDirect+DeathsIndirect
| summarize MinDamageWithCasualties=minif(Damage,(Deaths >0) and (Damage >0)) by State 
| where MinDamageWithCasualties >0 and isnotnull(MinDamageWithCasualties)

documentation.title: percentile(), percentiles()
documentation.description:
The `percentile()` function calculates an estimate for the specified nearest-rank percentile of the population defined by *expr*.
The accuracy depends on the density of population in the region of the percentile.

`percentiles()` works similarly to `percentile()`. However, `percentiles()` can calculate multiple percentile values at once, which is more efficient than calculating each percentile value separately.

To calculate weighted percentiles, see percentilesw().
documentation.returnInfo: Instead of returning the values in individual columns, use the `percentiles_array()` function to return the percentiles in a single column of dynamic array type. ### Syntax `percentiles_array(`*expr*`,` *percentiles*`)` ### Parameters | Name | Type | Required | Description | |:--|:--|:--|:--| |*expr* | `string` | *True* | The expression to use for aggregation calculation.| |*percentiles*| real or dynamic | *True*| One or more comma-separated percentiles or a dynamic array of percentiles. Each percentile must be a real value.| ### Returns Returns an estimate for *expr* of the specified percentiles in the group as a single column of dynamic array type. ### Examples #### Comma-separated percentiles Multiple percentiles can be obtained as an array in a single dynamic column, instead of in multiple columns as with percentiles(). :::moniker range="azure-data-explorer" > [!div class="nextstepaction"] > Run the query ::: moniker-end ```kusto TransformedSensorsData | summarize percentiles_array(Value, 5, 25, 50, 75, 95), avg(Value) by SensorName ``` **Output** The results table displays only the first 10 rows. |SensorName|percentiles_Value|avg_Value | |:--|:--|:--| |sensor-82|["0.048141473520867069","0.24407515500271132","0.48974511106780577","0.74160998970950343","0.94587903204190071"]|0.493950914| |sensor-130|["0.049200214398937764","0.25735850440187535","0.51206374010048239","0.74182335059053839","0.95210342463616771"]|0.505111463| |sensor-56|["0.04857779335488676","0.24709868149337144","0.49668762923789589","0.74458470404241883","0.94889104840865857"]|0.497955018| |sensor-24|["0.051507199150534679","0.24803904945640423","0.50397070213183581","0.75653888126010793","0.9518782718727431"]|0.501084379| |sensor-47|["0.045991246974755672","0.24644331118208851","0.48089197707088743","0.74475142784472248","0.9518322864959039"]|0.49386228| |sensor-135|["0.05132897529660399","0.24204987641954018","0.48470113942206461","0.74275730068433621","0.94784079559229406"]|0.494817619| |sensor-74|["0.048914714739047828","0.25160926036445724","0.49832498850160978","0.75257887767110776","0.94932261924236094"]|0.501627252| |sensor-173|["0.048333149363009836","0.26084250046756496","0.51288012531934613","0.74964772791583412","0.95156058795294"]|0.505401226| |sensor-28|["0.048511161184567046","0.2547387968731824","0.50101318228599656","0.75693845702682039","0.95243122486483989"]|0.502066244| |sensor-34|["0.049980293859462954","0.25094722564949412","0.50914023067384762","0.75571549713447961","0.95176564809278674"]|0.504309494| |...|...|...| #### Dynamic array of percentiles Percentiles for `percentiles_array` can be specified in a dynamic array of integer or floating-point numbers. The array must be constant but doesn't have to be literal. :::moniker range="azure-data-explorer" > [!div class="nextstepaction"] > Run the query ::: moniker-end ```kusto TransformedSensorsData | summarize percentiles_array(Value, dynamic([5, 25, 50, 75, 95])), avg(Value) by SensorName ``` **Output** The results table displays only the first 10 rows. |SensorName|percentiles_Value|avg_Value | |:--|:--|:--| |sensor-82|["0.048141473520867069","0.24407515500271132","0.48974511106780577","0.74160998970950343","0.94587903204190071"]|0.493950914| |sensor-130|["0.049200214398937764","0.25735850440187535","0.51206374010048239","0.74182335059053839","0.95210342463616771"]|0.505111463| |sensor-56|["0.04857779335488676","0.24709868149337144","0.49668762923789589","0.74458470404241883","0.94889104840865857"]|0.497955018| |sensor-24|["0.051507199150534679","0.24803904945640423","0.50397070213183581","0.75653888126010793","0.9518782718727431"]|0.501084379| |sensor-47|["0.045991246974755672","0.24644331118208851","0.48089197707088743","0.74475142784472248","0.9518322864959039"]|0.49386228| |sensor-135|["0.05132897529660399","0.24204987641954018","0.48470113942206461","0.74275730068433621","0.94784079559229406"]|0.494817619| |sensor-74|["0.048914714739047828","0.25160926036445724","0.49832498850160978","0.75257887767110776","0.94932261924236094"]|0.501627252| |sensor-173|["0.048333149363009836","0.26084250046756496","0.51288012531934613","0.74964772791583412","0.95156058795294"]|0.505401226| |sensor-28|["0.048511161184567046","0.2547387968731824","0.50101318228599656","0.75693845702682039","0.95243122486483989"]|0.502066244| |sensor-34|["0.049980293859462954","0.25094722564949412","0.50914023067384762","0.75571549713447961","0.95176564809278674"]|0.504309494| |...|...|...| *P*-th percentile (0 < *P* <= 100) of a list of ordered values, sorted in ascending order, is the smallest value in the list. The *P* percent of the data is less or equal to *P*-th percentile value (from Wikipedia article on percentiles). Define *0*-th percentiles to be the smallest member of the population. > > Given the approximating nature of the calculation, the actual returned value may not be a member of the population. > Nearest-rank definition means that *P*=50 does not conform to the interpolative definition of the median. When evaluating the significance of this discrepancy for the specific application, the size of the population and an estimation error should be taken into account. The percentiles aggregate provides an approximate value using T-Digest. > > > * The bounds on the estimation error vary with the value of the requested percentile. The best accuracy is at both ends of the [0..100] scale. Percentiles 0 and 100 are the exact minimum and maximum values of the distribution. The accuracy gradually decreases towards the middle of the scale. It's worst at the median and is capped at 1%. > * Error bounds are observed on the rank, not on the value. Suppose percentile(X, 50) returned a value of Xm. The estimate guarantees that at least 49% and at most 51% of the values of X are less or equal to Xm. There is no theoretical limit on the difference between Xm and the actual median value of X. > * The estimation may sometimes result in a precise value but there are no reliable conditions to define when it will be the case.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression to use for aggregation calculation.|
|*percentile*| real |  *True*| A constant that specifies the percentile.|
|*percentiles* | real |  *True* | One or more comma-separated percentiles.|

documentation.title: percentilew(), percentilesw()
documentation.description:
The `percentilew()` function calculates a weighted estimate for the specified nearest-rank percentile of the population defined by *expr*. `percentilesw()` works similarly to `percentilew()`. However, `percentilesw()` can calculate multiple weighted percentile values at once, which is more efficient than calculating each weighted percentile value separately.

Weighted percentiles calculate percentiles in a dataset by giving each value in the input dataset a weight. In this method, each value is considered to be repeated a number of times equal to its weight, which is then used to calculate the percentile. By giving more importance to certain values, weighted percentiles provide a way to calculate percentiles in a "weighted" manner.

To calculate unweighted percentiles, see percentiles().
documentation.returnInfo: Instead of returning the values in individual columns, use the `percentilesw_array()` function to return the percentiles in a single column of dynamic array type. ### Syntax `percentilesw_array(`*expr*`,` *weightExpr*`,` *percentiles*`)` ### Parameters | Name | Type | Required | Description | |:--|:--|:--|:--| |*expr* | `string` | *True* | The expression to use for aggregation calculation.| |*percentiles*| real or dynamic | *True*| One or more comma-separated percentiles or a dynamic array of percentiles. Each percentile must be a real value.| |*weightExpr*| `long` | *True*|The weight to give each value.| ### Returns Returns an estimate for *expr* of the specified percentiles in the group as a single column of dynamic array type. ### Examples The examples in this section show how to use the syntax to help you get started. #### Comma-separated percentiles :::moniker range="azure-data-explorer" > [!div class="nextstepaction"] > Run the query ::: moniker-end ```kusto let latencyTable = datatable (ReqCount:long, LatencyBucket:long) [ 8, 10, 6, 20, 3, 30, 1, 40 ]; latencyTable | summarize percentilesw_array(LatencyBucket, ReqCount, 50, 75, 99.9) ``` **Output** | percentile_LatencyBucket | |:---|:---|:---| | [20, 20, 40] | #### Dynamic array of percentiles :::moniker range="azure-data-explorer" > [!div class="nextstepaction"] > Run the query ::: moniker-end ```kusto let latencyTable = datatable (ReqCount:long, LatencyBucket:long) [ 8, 10, 6, 20, 3, 30, 1, 40 ]; latencyTable | summarize percentilesw_array(LatencyBucket, ReqCount, dynamic([50, 75, 99.9])) ``` **Output** | percentile_LatencyBucket | |:---|:---|:---| | [20, 20, 40] |
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression to use for aggregation calculation.|
|*weightExpr*| `long` | *True*|The weight to give each value.|
|*percentile*| real |  *True*| A constant that specifies the percentile.|
|*percentiles* | real |  *True* | One or more comma-separated percentiles.|

documentation.title: stdev()
documentation.description:
Calculates the standard deviation of *expr* across the group, using Bessel's correction for a small dataset that is considered a sample.

For a large dataset that is representative of the population, use stdevp() (aggregation function).
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the standard deviation value of *expr* across the group.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for the standard deviation aggregation calculation. |
documentation.example:
range x from 1 to 5 step 1
| summarize make_list(x), stdev(x)

documentation.title: stdevif()
documentation.description: Calculates the standard deviation of *expr* in records for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the standard deviation value of *expr* in records for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for the standards deviation aggregation calculation. |
| *predicate* | `string` |  *True* | The predicate that has to evaluate to `true` in order for *expr* to be added to the result. |
documentation.example:
range x from 1 to 100 step 1
| summarize stdevif(x, x % 2 == 0)

documentation.title: stdevp()
documentation.description:
Calculates the standard deviation of *expr* across the group, considering the group as a population for a large dataset that is representative of the population.

For a small dataset that is a sample, use stdev() (aggregation function).
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the standard deviation value of *expr* across the group.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for the standards deviation aggregation calculation. |
documentation.example:
range x from 1 to 5 step 1
| summarize make_list(x), stdevp(x)

documentation.title: sum()
documentation.description: Calculates the sum of *expr* across the group.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the sum value of *expr* across the group.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr*  string |  *True* | The expression used for the aggregation calculation. |
documentation.example:
StormEvents 
| summarize EventCount=count(), TotalDamages = sum(DamageCrops+DamageProperty) by State 
| sort by TotalDamages

documentation.title: sumif()
documentation.description:
Calculates the sum of *expr* in records for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.

You can also use the sum() function, which sums rows without predicate expression.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the sum of *expr* for which *predicate* evaluates to `true`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for the aggregation calculation. |
| *predicate* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used to filter rows. If the predicate evaluates to `true`, the row will be included in the result.|

documentation.title: take_any()
documentation.description:
Arbitrarily chooses one record for each group in a summarize operator,
and returns the value of one or more expressions over each such record.

> **Deprecated aliases:** any()

> 
> The deprecated version adds `any_` prefix to the columns returned by the `any()` aggregation.
documentation.returnInfo:
The `take_any` aggregation function returns the values of the expressions calculated
for each of the records selected Indeterministically from each group of the summarize operator.

If the `*` argument is provided, the function behaves as if the expressions are all columns
of the input to the summarize operator barring the group-by columns, if any.

This function is useful when you want to get a sample value of one or more columns
per value of the compound group key.

When the function is provided with a single column reference, it will attempt to
return a non-null/non-empty value, if such value is present.

As a result of the indeterministic nature of this function, using this function multiple times in
a single application of the `summarize` operator isn't equivalent to using
this function a single time with multiple expressions. The former may have each application
select a different record, while the latter guarantees that all values are calculated
over a single record (per distinct group).
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr_N* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for selecting a record. If the wildcard value (`*`) is given in place of an expression, all records will be selected.|
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| summarize take_any(State)

StormEvents
| project StartTime, EpisodeId, State, EventType
| summarize take_any(*)

StormEvents
| where State startswith "A"
| project StartTime, EpisodeId, State, EventType
| summarize take_any(*) by State

documentation.title: take_anyif()
documentation.description:
Arbitrarily selects one record for each group in a summarize operator in records for which the *predicate*
is 'true'. The function returns the value of an expression over each such record.

This function is useful when you want to get a sample value of one column per value of the compound group key, subject to some predicate that is *true*. If such a value is present, the function attempts to return a non-null/non-empty value.

> **Deprecated aliases:** anyif()

> 
> The deprecated version adds `any_` prefix to the columns returned by the `any()` aggregation.
documentation.returnInfo:
The `take_anyif` aggregation function returns the value of the expression calculated
for each of the records randomly selected from each group of the summarize operator. Only records for which *predicate* returns 'true' may be selected. If the predicate doesn't return 'true', a null value is produced.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for selecting a record. |
| *predicate* | `string` |  *True* | Indicates which records may be considered for evaluation. |
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| summarize take_anyif(EventType, EventNarrative has 'strong wind')

documentation.title: tdigest()
documentation.description:
Calculates the intermediate results of `percentiles()` across the group.

For more information, see the underlying algorithm (T-Digest) and the estimated error.

> 
> The results of tdigest() and tdigest_merge() can be stored and later retrieved. For example, you may want to create daily percentiles summary, which can then be used to calculate weekly percentiles.
> However, the precise binary representation of these results may change over time, and is not documented. There's no guarantee that these functions will produce identical results for identical inputs.
documentation.returnInfo:
The Intermediate results of weighted percentiles of `*expr*` across the group.

> 
>
>- Use the aggregation function tdigest_merge() to merge the output of `tdigest` again across another group.
>- Use the function percentile_tdigest() to calculate the percentile/percentilew of the `tdigest` results.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for the aggregation calculation. |
| *weight* | `string` | | The weights of the values for the aggregation calculation. |

documentation.title: tdigest_merge()
documentation.description:
Merges tdigest results across the group.

For more information about the underlying algorithm (T-Digest) and the estimated error, see estimation error in percentiles.

> The `tdigest_merge()` and `merge_tdigest()` functions are equivalent

> 
>The results of tdigest() and tdigest_merge() can be stored and later retrieved. For example, you may want to create daily percentiles summary, which can then be used to calculate weekly percentiles.
> However, the precise binary representation of these results may change over time. There's no guarantee that these functions will produce identical results for identical inputs, and therefore we don't advise relying on them.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns the merged tdigest values of *expr* across the group.

> 
>
> * Use the function percentile_tdigest() to calculate the percentiles from the `tdigest_merge` results.
> * All tdigests that are included in the same group must be of the same type.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*expr* | `string` |  *True* | The expression used for the aggregation calculation.|
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| summarize PreAggDamageProperty=tdigest(DamageProperty) by State
| summarize tdigest_merge(PreAggDamageProperty)

Calculates the variance of *expr* across the group, considering the group as a sample.

documentation.example:
